body.p: I like to avoid threads, so I naively hoped that V8 did not require them. But V8 does require threads (uses pthreads to be specific), so your V8 application will be multi-threaded. You get some control over how many "extra" threads are started, but it can't be zeo. See this StackOverflow question.

To be clear, ECMAScript is single-threaded, so V8's implementation of that language is likely to always be as well. As this overview implies, combining a single-threaded interpreted language with the ability to hand off I/O bound tasks to the external environment is a good compromise. The vague idea that JavaScript is "missing" threads is misplaced. If JavaScript had threads, node.js would never have gotten off the ground. Protecting the masses of programmers from multi-threading is more important than protecting them from memory management. As Gordon Bell warns, Parallelism is more difficult to implement than anyone imagines.

Of course, since V8 lets you run multiple JavaScript engines in the same process, you are always free to have more than one single-threaded JavaScript environment operating at the same time. You have to arrange for them to communicate, however, if they are sharing the work, just like a web browser has to use a clunky message-posting mechanism to make "web workers" (background JavaScript "threads") actually work.
The V8 library includes mild support for this. But I haven't studied it, so may be deeply confused.
